{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3409478,"name":"Emil","username":"GronkBaby","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/g/ba8739/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-07-19T13:11:35.736Z","cooked":"

Hi everyone!

I really want to try making a button-board, with buttons corresponding to things like ‚Äúintake broken‚Äù, ‚Äúlocalization not working‚Äù, ‚Äútest mode‚Äù, and switch between robot states. But I don‚Äôt understand how

(a) a microcontroller can tell the difference between each button being pressed? I initially thought about giving each button circuit a different resistance and measuring the voltage when pressed (since it completes the circuit), and based on that, deciding what button has been pressed. From my understanding of basic microcontrollers like an arduino, I‚Äôm pretty sure I can also put each button on a separate IO pin, but with this approach there is a limit to how many buttons I can use.

(b) how do I communicate what buttons are being pressed with my roborio?

I‚Äôm aware that there exists button boards that are somewhat off the shelf that will register as an xbox controller, but this feels like cheating and I think it won‚Äôt be as much of a learning experience.

I‚Äôm somewhat of a novice when it comes to electronics, so I‚Äôd appreciate any help.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2024-07-19T13:18:46.892Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":961,"reads":542,"readers_count":541,"score":4898.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":468860,"topic_slug":"how-does-a-button-board-work","display_username":"Emil","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/2-way-arduino-joystick-pad-communication/472675/3","internal":true,"reflection":true,"title":"2-way Arduino Joystick/pad communication","clicks":4}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":64351,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/how-does-a-button-board-work/468860/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3409482,"name":"Andrew McBride","username":"AndrewMcb","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/ec9cab/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-07-19T13:35:23.118Z","cooked":"

(b) is an easy one to answer and will help with my answer to (a). It is typically the FRC Driver Station that communicates button presses from a usb device over to the rio.

For (a), It is often used as each button is on a separate digital IO pin, with joysticks and other analog devices being connected to analog IO pins. The concern about the limit to how many buttons you can use it often not a valid concern because the Driverstation from point (b) already has a limit to how many buttons can be used per USB device that is generally lower than the amount of digital IO pins on the microcontroller being used.

As far as what it shows up as in windows, I wouldn‚Äôt be overly concerned with that. If it shows up as a GenericHID or an XboxController or something else, just as long as the controller shows up as an HID Device, you should be fine. For many Arduino/Pi level of controllers, reducing it to the point where it shows up as an HID device will be the difficult part.

You might find these threads informative:

Button Board General Forum
At regionals we saw several teams using button boards. I can see the benefit to them, and would like to build one to play with. If you use one, can you help us with the following? What kits are you using? How difficult is it to program using java? Is there any special programming that has to be done to get the buttons working for the robot other than the standard button mapping?
Button Box/Button Board Recommendations? General Forum
Teams that use button boards as part of their driving, what do you use?

Definitely check out the other threads on the topic as I‚Äôm not going to go into any specific hardware here just the high level concepts.

These days there are two typical ways that robot drivers communicate with the robot. 1st is through the DriverStation Software and second is through NetworkTables.

For the Former, you can connect up anything (wired) that will/can appear as a GeneridHID/Joystick/Gamepad device to Windows and thus in the DriverStation software as well as read in some kind of inputs from physical hardware (buttons/switches/potentiometers, etc.). Typically this is either by programming a micro-controller capable of running a USB Client Stack and emulating a Joystick/Gamepad, or using a purpose built USB Joystick Board such as the very accessible ones designed to connect up PC-based Arcade Cabinet style buttons/joysticks. This data is then accessible on the Robot same as any other Joystick data.

For the Latter, you have additional software running on the DriverStation Laptop that somehow reads/writes data to NetworkTables either directly or perhaps through a Plugin for Shuffleboard or some other Dashboard. The Robot can then also read/write to NetworkTables. This method is far more flexible, but I personally would not use this for any critical robot functionality if possible.

I myself have previously brainstormed on a possible hybrid system that sends inputs primarily over the DriverStation, but is also able to read NetworkTables to display Robot Statuses or something using LEDs or a 7-seg display on a button board.

Regarding (a), the way mechanical keyboards detect presses without having a different pin for each key is called matrix scanning.

hackaday.io

Keyboard Matrix Scanning | Details | Hackaday.io

Early in my college years I came across this very useful and web based animated circuit simulator, falstad.com/circuit. Since I'm a hands on and visual learner, this tool really helped me grasp the behavior of electronic and logic circuits. While...

We used it for our 2023 button board, which was a Raspberry Pi Pico-based numpad kit with custom CircuitPython firmware.

image2956√ó3941 1.42 MB

Using something like a RP2040 MacroPad from Adafruit makes things easier. You can program one to appear as a standard gamepad so it‚Äôs easy to interface with in the robot program.

And it‚Äôs got RGB LEDs under each key, and a small display that you can use to describe the function of each key.

adafruit.com

Adafruit MacroPad RP2040 Starter Kit - 3x4 Keys + Encoder + OLED

Strap yourself in, we're launching in T-minus 10 seconds...Destination? A new Class M planet called MACROPAD! M here stands for Microcontroller because this 3x4 keyboard controller ...

Price: $49.95 USD

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2024-07-20T00:43:47.347Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":16,"reads":248,"readers_count":247,"score":144.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":468860,"topic_slug":"how-does-a-button-board-work","display_username":"Nick Anastasoff","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://mitchtech.net/arduino-usb-hid-keyboard/","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Mitchtech - Arduino USB HID Keyboard","clicks":22},{"url":"https://github.com/first-team-58/Toaster/blob/main/toaster.ino","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Toaster/toaster.ino at main ¬∑ first-team-58/Toaster ¬∑ GitHub","clicks":16}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":57441,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/how-does-a-button-board-work/468860/7","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3409733,"name":"Brett B Bonner","username":"bbonner","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bbonner/{size}/155176_2.png","created_at":"2024-07-20T16:24:46.071Z","cooked":"

As with so many things, there‚Äôs more than one way to do this. Others have good suggestions above, I‚Äôll add a few things.

6328 uses one of these off-the-shelf arcade controller boards as the electronic interface for the override switches on our operator consoles. (Scroll down a bit for a photo of the controller under the switches.) These are great for switches/buttons but don‚Äôt offer analog inputs (as you‚Äôd need for joysticks), though you can find others that do have this.

If you want to DIY it, you typically want something that can emulate a USB joystick/game pad. There‚Äôs a bunch of options, but a ATmega32u4 based Arduino like the ‚ÄúLeonardo‚Äù is an obvious possibility since it can directly emulate USB devices. Given buttons and perhaps some external pull-up resistors, it‚Äôs pretty simple to read inputs. The Cypress board that was (is?) included with the KoP for a while is also something I see teams using pretty often.

Driving outputs is harder. When we experimented with a very fancy operator board, it presented a serial-over-USB interface for driving its outputs (plus 2 emulating 2 joysticks in order to support enough buttons), and we ran a custom Python script on the driver station laptop that read state from NetworkTables and sent custom serial commands to the Leonardo that controlled the board.

Anything handling driver/operator input needs to be rock solid since it‚Äôs critical to successful match play. Make sure whatever you do is carefully built and thoroughly tested so the drive team has confidence in it.

Electrical/Controls"},"post_url":"/t/how-does-a-button-board-work/468860/8","custom_user_title":"6328 Mentor - Electrical/Controls","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3417942,"name":"BrianAtlanta","username":"BrianAtlanta","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/brianatlanta/{size}/7578_2.png","created_at":"2024-08-25T06:45:57.373Z","cooked":"

How do the buttons/switches from the arcade controller board present in code? We‚Äôre using Java.

Do you just use the joystick class and just access getRawButton(1) for example?

You would use GenericHID, not Joystick, but yes.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2024-08-25T06:55:55.283Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":9,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":177,"readers_count":176,"score":60.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":468860,"topic_slug":"how-does-a-button-board-work","display_username":"Amicus1","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":23042,"username":"BrianAtlanta","name":"BrianAtlanta","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/brianatlanta/{size}/7578_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":33946,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"6995A/Choreo/Monologue"},"post_url":"/t/how-does-a-button-board-work/468860/10","custom_user_title":"6995A/Choreo/Monologue","reactions":[{"id":"+1","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3417961,"name":"Brett B Bonner","username":"bbonner","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bbonner/{size}/155176_2.png","created_at":"2024-08-25T13:38:02.772Z","cooked":"
BrianAtlanta:

How do the buttons/switches from the arcade controller board present in code?

You can see the code for the override switches here. But as @Amicus1 noted below, yes, it‚Äôs accessed via GenericHID. That‚Äôs one of the things we like about them - nothing special is needed, they Just Work‚Ñ¢.

If you‚Äôre building a custom operator console, please make sure it complies with the rules in section 8.9, particularly R904B, which says it can be no more than 14 inches deep. Don‚Äôt wait until inspection to find out that your lovingly hand-crafted button box is larger than the driver station shelf.

yes, it‚Äôs common to use an Arduino as a button board. the driver station supports up to 32 boolean inputs per controller. you could encode the hardware as ‚Äúone hot‚Äù and get 32 buttons pressed in any combination, or you could support only one pressed at a time, and support, uh, 4 billion buttons?
